summary: Email correspondence between a law firm attorney and a federal prosecutor regarding a potential witness's willingness to testify in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial. The witness requires financial assistance for family travel to New York for the July trial and may use funds from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Fund.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.role: Attorney at Searcy Denney Barnhart & Shipley, P.A.
persons.context: Attorney communicating with a federal prosecutor about a witness's testimony and travel arrangements for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: Recipient of emails discussing witness testimony and logistical arrangements for the upcoming trial.

connections.person2: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
connections.description: Attorney and prosecutor coordinating on witness testimony for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial.

events.title: Ghislaine Maxwell Trial
events.description: Upcoming trial in New York where a witness is being asked to testify.
personsInvolved: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York

keyFacts: A witness is willing to testify at the Ghislaine Maxwell trial in July 2021 but requires her husband and children to accompany her to New York.
The witness lacks the financial means to pay for her family's travel and may use funds from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Fund to partially cover expenses.
The correspondence involves coordination between a private attorney and a federal prosecutor regarding witness logistics and government commitments.
The document highlights the practical challenges and financial barriers faced by victims/witnesses in participating in high-profile trials.
